Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Advanced Energy Data Analytics, Visualization, and Forecasting Platform for Energy Decision-Makers
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project includes developing an analytical platform is capable of empowering customers with big-data analytical capacity, allow them to design and test clean energy ideas on their own terms at a fast pace using evidence-based machine-learning-enabled algorithms, and to enhance their capability to communicate with stakeholders. By adopting the proposed technology, its users could reduce energy consumption, save financial and physical resources, and minimize environmental impact. The predictive feature of the technology could also allow its users to develop a long-term view about their individual purchasing behavior as well as collective planning actions, and make financially wise and environmentally friendly decisions regarding home appliance purchases, commercial technology deployment, as well as city and regional planning.

This I-Corps project aims to explore the commercial viability of an energy analytics platform that combines big-data management platforms, electricity financial models, machine-learning-enabled data-driven analytical tools, and a 3D visualization interface. The platform is pre-loaded with historical data that allows customers to benchmark their past electricity use patterns. The historical data will also serve as an input to customizable machine-learning algorithms that provide customers the power and flexibility to design evidence-driven actions that fit their electricity consumption needs and forecast the economic, environmental, and social impacts related to the actions in the mid- to long-term. Users of the technology will be able to track and assess their electricity use and expenditures, and any associated capital investments. The technology will also allow its users to see the social and macro-economic impact of their energy-related action by producing outputs on public health, job creation and local GDP growth.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the NSF-funded project titled Advanced Energy Data Analytics, Visualization, and Forecasting Platform for Energy Decision-Makers, the team conducted over 120 interviews with professionals from environmental NGOs, power utility companies, Fortune 500 companies, and federal, state and local government officials to understand their needs and desires when it comes to making energy decisions, pursuing clean energy actions and designing sustainability programs.

The market discovery interviews provided the team with insights into different potential customer segment. The team found that the environmental NGOs, philanthropic foundations with a clean energy focus, and local governments with sustainability goals are the most welcoming market segments. Most corporations are not ready to fine-tune investments into clean energy goals, although first movers like Apple, Google, and Facebook, are changing industry discussions. The barrier to entry is too high in the power utility sector. This segment usually requires significant marketing and sales effort and long (several years) approval times.

One of the key outcomes is that the project enables a software product focusing on analyzing the electric power market and clean energy to be further developed according to customer needs. Two customer discovery insights were particularly impactful: 1. NGO and government customers are sophisticated, and they desire quantitative analytical tools that can help them quickly assess multiple action scenarios with high accuracy. 2. The same customers like impact metrics to include more than just traditional energy and environmental measures. They want to have broader social benefit measures such as the improvement resulting from clean energy actions in public health, job creation, economic development, economic equality, and affordable housing.

The software product is capable of conducting rapid scenario analyses. The accuracy of the carbon emission assessment tool is over a thousand times better than existing products on the market because the team developed a revolutionary method using both high resolution temporal utility data and machine learning algorithms to forecast future environmental impacts coming from electricity generation. This approach significantly improves upon existing methodologies, expanding the understanding of how public data sources could be connected and utilized to create better analytical outcomes.

Furthermore, the software is capable of assessing a suite of co-benefits related to clean energy actions in order to better articulate the societal outcomes for decisionmakers. For example, the methodology developed by the team to unpack energy burdens at a granular geographic level for all demographic groups is ground breaking. It improves on the classic county-level and metropolitan-statistical-area-level energy burden analysis by drilling down to the neighborhood level and by including all utilities as opposed to just electricity.

As a result of the successful software development derived from the market discover findings, a new organization with a heavy focus on providing services to municipal governments, NGOs and philanthropic foundations is blossoming. The Greenlink Group, the principal developer of the software and the business lead of this project, is growing at a healthy pace 14 months after the conclusion of the workshop.

The economic development impact of the project is encouraging. The Greenlink Group has created 2 new full-time employment opportunities and one half-time position. Two of them are software engineering positions, and one is a data analyst position. Two of the three positions employ STEM-major professionals. Two of the employees are women. The project also created a 10-week internship position for a Georgia Tech Ph. D student.

Last but not least, the team is particularly proud of the applications of the technology to the targeted markets and the profound impact it has achieved so far. The software technology has been used to answer real world policy analysis and program design questions in eight states and more than a dozen cities to help governments and organizations engage in more clean energy actions. The results of these actions are commitments and financial investments into clean energy projects like solar, wind, energy efficiency, and electric vehicles. This has a profound impact on the nation?s energy infrastructure and the general public?s health and overall wellbeing.

In summary, through the project, the team has created a software technology and then used it to empower policymakers with nuanced understanding about how energy, environment, economy, and society interact. With the past and ongoing projects partnering with cities, national NGOs, and philanthropic foundations, the team has equipped institutional actors like government agencies, lawmakers, and environmental advocates and professionals with a new mindset, foundational to building a low-carbon economy.
